metadata.title: Cell Reports Supplemental Information IFITM Proteins Restrict HIV-1 Infection by Antagonizing the Envelope Glycoprotein

body_text.text: Env processing. PM1 cells stably expressing shRNA against IFITM1, 2 or 3 were infected with VSV-G pseudotyped NL43; 48 hours after infection, virions were harvested and purified from supernatant and cells pellets were lysed by RIPA buffer and subjected to immunoprecipitation and western blots. We constantly found that IFITM3 and IFITM1 shRNA-expressing cells were more vulnerable to NL43 infection, exhibiting rapidly syncytia formation and cell death, as reflected by relatively low GAPDH expression (lane 3 and 5, bottom panel) (B) . Possible reason include that shRNA IFITM1 can cross-knock down both IFITM1 and IFITM3, while IFITM3 shRNA can knockdown all three IFITMs (See Figure 2A) , resulting in significant viral infection and rapid syncytia formation thus cell death. Quantification of Env processing was performed by calculating gp120/gp160 or gp41/gp160 ratio (C). Results represent 2-5 independent experiments, * p < 0.05. Purified virions from PM1 cells were analyzed for gp120, gp41 and p24 (D). Figure S3 . Analysis of interactions between IFITM chimeras and HIV-1 Env. Related to Figure 3 . Methods and procedures are the same as was described in Figure 3 for parental IFITMs except that some IFITM mutants were transfected into 293T cells for analysis. Figure S4 . Effects of IFITM3 on the processing and interactions with HIV-1 Env mutants. Related to Figure 6 . Experimental approaches were the same as described for HIV-1 WT in the Figure 3 legend, except that HIV-1 escape mutant EnvA539V and the Env∆CT construct were analyzed. (A) Upper panels indicate cell lysates input, and lower panels show immunoprecipitation of cell lysates with anti-FLAG conjugated beads. Note that while the EnvA539V escape mutant was still associated with IFITM3 as the Env WT, the Env∆CT mutant substantially lost its interaction with IFITM3 as evidenced by reduced anti-gp160 and gp41 blots. Also note that the anti-gp41 antibody, 2F5, which was used here, was not efficient to detect immunoprecipiated gp41 even though it can reasonably detect gp41 protein from cell lysates; we cannot use Chassie 8 antibody here as was used in Figure 3 because it was generated against the CT of HIV-1 Env and would not be able to detect the Env∆CT. (B) Upper panels indicate concentrated virion inputs, and lower panels show immunoprecipitation of virions HIV-Ig conjugated beads. Note equivalent gp120 in virions for Env∆CT with or without IFITM3, supporting the conclusion that Env∆CT is resistant to IFITM3. Figure 7 . Experimental procedures were the same as described in Figure 7 , except that the absolute luciferase activities of viral infections were plotted and shown. Note some differences between cell-to-cell and cell-free infections of the same virus in the absence of IFITMs, as well as the differences between different viruses in cellto-cell or cell-free infection. For example, despite extremely low cell-free infection of SIVcpz in HeLa-TZM cells, the cell-to-cell transmission/fusion of SIVcpz between 293T and HeLa-TZM was quite efficient. In contrast, the cell-to-cell infection of HIV-1 YU2 from Jurkat/inGluc to PBMCs was extremely low compared to other viruses, yet the cell-free infection of YU2 in PBMCs was comparable to that of NL43 and BH10. We cannot rule out the possibility that these differential patterns may be cell type-dependent. Comparisons between cell-to-cell (first 4 columns) and cell-free infections (second 4 columns) of different HIV-1, HIV-2, and SIV strains are also shown in (E) and (F). The fold differences are indicated. Results represent 2-5 independent experiments, with all samples done in duplicates. ** p < 0.01; *** p < 0.001. The HIV-1 molecular clone pNL(AD8) has been previously described (Freed and Martin, 1994) .
body_text.section: (B-D) Knockdown of IFITMs in PM1 cells increases HIV-1NL43

body_text.text: NL43(AD8) is an NL43-derived molecular clone that contains a portion of the macrophage-13 tropic AD8 Env and thus uses the CCR5 coreceptor for entry (Freed and Martin, 1994) . YU2 is a 14 primary HIV-1 isolate that also uses CCR5. The HIV-1 NL43 mutants Vpu40, EnvA539A and In some cases, we applied an HIV-1 NL43 -iGFP-based system to measure viral antigen (Gag) 20 transfer. Briefly, HIV-1 NL43 -iGFP and IFITM plasmids were transfected into HEK293T cells, 21 and 24 hours after transfection, donor 293T cells were mixed with Jurkat-Tdtomato cells at 1:1 22 ratio on 24-well plates. Cells were cocultured for different periods of time and HIV-1 Gag-GFP 23 transfer was quantified gating Jurkat-TdTomato cells using flow cytometry or by live cell 1 imaging.

HIV-1 intron Gaussia luciferase(inGLuc)-based coculture system as was originally described by 4 Derse and colleagues (Mazurov et al., 2010) . This assay takes advantage that an intron, which 5 was inserted into an HIV-1 vector in an opposite orientation to the Luc ORF, can be removed In all cases, no effect of IFITM expression on cell viability or proliferation capacity of the 22 donor cells was found. Cell-cell fusion. 293T cells were transfected with Env-encoding plasmids, either HIV-1 Env or 14 IAV HA, along with LXSN expressing HIV-1 Tat (for HIV-1 Env). Twenty-four hours after 15 transfection, cells were cocultured with HeLa-TZM at 1:1 ratio for 24 h, lysed, and measured for 16 firefly luciferase activity. Proteins were quantified by Bradford assay and used to normalize the 17 cell-cell fusion activity. All samples were tested in duplicates, and the results were averaged.

BIBREF2.title: Quantitative 3D video microscopy of HIV 14 transfer across T cell virological synapses

BIBREF4.title: IFITM Proteins Restrict Viral Membrane Hemifusion

BIBREF7.title: Putative phosphatidylinositol 3-Kianse (PI3K) 22 binding motifs in ovine betaretrovirus Env proteins are not essential for rodent fibroblast 23 transformation and PI3K/Akt activation

FIGREF0.text: Live-cell imaging of HIV-1 infection from 293T to Jurkat (A) and 293T to HeLa-TZM (B) cells. Related to Figure 1. Representative images showing the inhibitory effect of IFITM3 on HIV-1 cell-to-cell infection and fusion. Methods are the same as described inFigure 1F. Arrows indicate double positive cells, indicative of HIV-1 transfer and fusion. Note that in pQCXIP control cells, giant floating cells were observed due to syncytia formation-induced cell death.

FIGREF1.text: Effect of endogenous IFITM on HIV-1 cell-to-cell transmission and Env processing. Related to Figure 2. (A) Flow cytometric profiles of HIV-1NL43-iGFP transfer from PM1 to Jurkat cells.

FIGREF3.text: Effects of IFITMs on cell-to-cell or cell-free infection of HIV-1 BH10, YU2 and AD8, as well as on HIV-2 and SIV isolates. Related to

FIGREF4.text: Cell--to--cell VS. Cell--free R e la t iv e tr a n s m is s IFITMs do not significantly affect the expression of HIV-1 Env, CXCR4 coreceptor, and other critical cellular molecules involved in formation of virological synapse (VS). Related to "cell-to-cell infection" in experimental procedures. (A) 293T cells were transiently with plasmids encoding IFITMs, and the expression of IFITMs (detected by using anti-FLAG), HIV-1 Env (2G12 recognizing both gp120 and gp160), CXCR4, ICAM-1 and LFA-1 was examined by flow cytometry. (B) Jurkat cells stably expressing IFITM1, 2, 3 or none were examined for CXCR4, CD63, CD81, CD4, LFA-1 and ICAM-1 by flow cytometry. Parental cells are set as negative control (gray, no staining). Experiments were repeated once, with similar results obtained.

FIGREF5.text: Expression of IFITMs does not reduce HIV-1 transfer from Jurkat to primary CD4+ T cells. Related to Related to "cell-to-cell infection" in experimental procedures. (A) Jurkat cells were transfected with HIV-1 Gag-iCherry and pQCXIP encoding IFITMs or none. Target primary CD4+ T cells were mixed with donor Jurkat cells, and co-incubated for 4 hours; cells were fixed with 2% PFA and analyzed by flow cytometry. Representative FACS plots are shown. (B) Quantification of HIV-1 Gag-iCherry transfer efficiency from flow cytometry data (mean ± SEM; two independent experiments; NS, non-significant). (C) Flow cytometric imaging (Amnis) was performed on donor cells expressing Gag-iCherry, which were mixed with target primary CD4+ T cells after incubation for 4 hours (bar, 10 µm). Stable associations between donor and target cells were identified as follows: cells were sorted for doublets based on a single cell staining positive for cell-tracker (target cells) and the second cell positive for iCherry (donor). Bright-field images and HIV-Gag-iCherry are shown.Plasmids, cells and reagents.FLAG-tagged human IFITM1, IFITM2 and IFITM3 were cloned 3 into pQCXIP retroviral vector as previously reported(Li et al., 2013; Lu et al., 2011); these4 constructs have been shown to function similarly as their parental versions. Mutants IFITM1112, 5 IFITM2221, IFITM1222, IFITM2111, IFITM3-YL/AA, IFITM3-Y20A, IFITM3-L23A, 6 IFITM3∆1-21, IFITM1∆(112-125), IFITM1∆(117-125), IFITM1∆(108-125) were all tagged 7 with FLAG and generated by PCR-based mutagenesis using parental pQCXIP-IFITM1, 2 or 3 8 constructs as templates. The proviral HIV-1 NL43 (Cat#114), HIV-1 BH10 (Cat#90), SIV cpz Cat#11498), SIV Agm (Cat#3444), SIV Mac (Cat#210), HIV-2 Rod-1 (#207), YU2 (Cat#1350) 10 constructs were obtained from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) AIDS Reagent Program.11

FIGREF6.text: EnvA539V were generated by site-directed mutagenesis. The HIV-1 inGLuc vector was 16 obtained from David Derse (National Cancer Institute, Frederick, MD) (Mazurov et al., 2010).17The HIV-iGFP and iCherry constructs were previously reported(Hubner et al., 2009). JSRV Env 18 has been previously described(Côté et al., 2008). IAV HA was a gift of Gary Nabel(NIH,   19    Bethesda, MD). The plasmids encoding lentiviral shRNA against IFITM1, 2, 3 and scramble20 control were purchased from Sigma (St. Louis, MO).21 HEK293T and HeLa/TZM indicator cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's 22 medium (DMEM), supplemented with 0.5% penicillin/streptomycin and 10% FBS. Jurkat 23 the cell debris. Viruses were used to infect target HeLa-TZM cells in the presence s instructions (Promega, Madison, WI). In some cases, viral supernatants were 4 concentrated by ultracentrifugation at 32,000 rpm (Sorvall, Discovery 100SE) for 2 h at 4 °C, 5 and the purified virus was dissolved in PBS and used for immunoprecipitation or examined by Cell-to-cell infection. (A) HEK293T-to-Jurkat cells. Briefly, 293T cells were transfected with 9 HIV-1 pNL4.3-inGLuc, Gag-Pol, NL43 Env, in the presence or absence of IFITM-encoding 10 plasmids. Twenty-four hours post transfection, the donor 293T cells were detached using 5 mM 11 EDTA/PBS solution, and cocultured with target Jurkat cells at 1:1 ratio in poly-L-lysine-coated 12 24-well plates. Different inhibitors or antibodies were applied to coculture if necessary. 13 Following 24-48 hours coculture, supernatants were harvested, and Gaussia luciferase activity 14 was measured. To control cell-free viral infection, we mixed the mock-transfected donor 293T 15 cells with normal target Jurkat cells using exactly the same cell numbers as that were used in 16 cell-to-cell infection, and these cells were infected with supernatants harvested from donor 293T 17 cells (cotransfected IFITMs and HIV-1) that had been cultured for the same period of time as for 18 cell-to-cell infection (24-48 h). The GLuc activity was measured 24-48 hours after infection.19

FIGREF7.text: transduction of target cells; the Gluc gene is not expressed in transfected or 7 infected donor cells. We infected Jurkat/inGLuc cells expressing or not expressing IFITMs, or 8 PM1 cells stably expressing shRNA IFITMs or scramble RNA, with VSV-G pseudotyped HIV-9 1 NL43 . The VSV-G pseudotyped HIV-1 was used because they can efficiently infect donor cells 10 (almost 100%) therefore enhances capability of detection of cell-to-cell infection. Twelve hours 11 after infection, the donor Jurkat/inGLuc or PM1 cells were cocultured with target Jurkat cells at 12 1:1 ratio in 96-well plates. In parallel, exactly the same numbers of normal Jurkat/inGLuc or 13 PM1 and Jurkat cells were seeded for cell-free HIV-1 infection as described above for 293T-to-14 Jurkat cell transmission; 24-48 h after coculture or infection, GLuc activity was measured for 15 cell-to-cell infection and cell-free HIV-1 infection. 16 For HIV-1 NL43 -iGFP-or HIV-1 NL43 -iCherry-based system, PBMCs or Jurkat cells were 17 transfected with HIV-1 Gag-iGFP or Gag-iCherry plus pQCXIP empty vector or pQCXIP 18 vectors encoding IFITMs. Target Jurkat/tdTomato or primary CD4 + T cells were mixed with 19 donor cells and co-incubated for 4 hours, fixed with 2% Paraformaldehyde (PFA), and analyzed 20 by flow cytometry.

FIGREF9.text: . Cells were cotransfected with 1 µg HIV-1 NL43 -iGFP and either 1 µg pQCXIP-empty 3 vector or 1 µg pQCXIP vector encoding IFITM1, 2, or 3. Twenty-four hours post-transfection, 4 cells were detached using 5 mM EDTA in PBS solution, and cocultured with either Jurkat cells 5 stably expressing tdTomato or HeLa-TZM cells in Lab-Tek glass chamber slides coated with 6 0.01% poly-L-lysine. Cells were overlaid with 0.4% agarose and imaged using a fluorescent7 microscope (Leica) for over a period of 24 hours. To determine the percent transmission/fusion 8 of HIV-1 NL4.3-iGFP from 293T cells to Jurkat/tdTomato cells, the ratio of double positive cells 9 (cells containing both TdTomato and GFP) to HIV-1 NL4.3-iGFP-only cells was calculated.10 Normally 15-20 random areas were selected for counting. For 293T cells cocultured with HeLa-11 TZM cells, images were taken every 10 min for 20-24 hours.12 13 Immunoprecipitation and western blotting. Western blotting was performed as previously 14 described(Côté et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2003). Briefly, transfected 293T cells or HIV-1 infected 15 PM1 cells were collected, washed once by PBS, and lysed in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris pH 7.5, 16 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS). To examine possible interactions 17 between IFITMs and HIV-1 Env, we co-transfected 293T cells with HIV-1 NL43 or mutants along 18 with pQCXIP empty vector or pQCXIP expressing FLAG-tagged IFITMs or mutants. Cell 19 lysates were immunoprecipitated by using an anti-FLAG antibody and blotted with anti-HIV-1 20 Env antibodies (gp120 or gp41) or anti-Gag (p24). For PM1 cells, HIV-1 infected cells were 21 lysed with RIPA buffer and subjected to immunoprecipitation using pooled antibodies against 22 IFITM1, 2 and 3; western blots were performed using anti-HIV-1 Env (gp41). To examine if 23 1 encoding and NL43 plasmids were first subjected to ultracentrifugation; the purified pellets were 2 resuspended with PBS and immunoprecipitated with mixed HIV-1 immunoglobulin (HIV-Ig) 3 (NIH AIDS reagent program, Cat#3957)). The cell lysates and viral particles were dissolved in 4 sample buffer, separated on 10% SDS/PAGE, and detected by using anti-HIV-1 p24, anti-HIV-1 5 gp41, anti-gp120, anti-FLAG, or anti-β-actin antibodies. Pulse-chase labeling. HEK293T cells were transfected with HIV-1 proviral DNA along with an 8 IFITM3 expression plasmid. Twenty-four hour post-transfection, cells were starved with DMEM 9 without Cystine and Methionine (MP Biomedicals, LLC) for 30 min and pulse-labelied for 1 h in 10 DMEM media containing 62.5 µCi 35 S-Met/Cys. Cells were then chase-labeled for 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 4 11 and 6 h, respectively, followed by lysis in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 1 12 mM EDTA, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS). At each time point, the supernatants containing shed 13 gp120 were harvested. The harvested cell lysates and supernatants were respectively 14 immunoprecipitated with rProtein A beads (GE Healthcare) preconjugated with 5 µg AIDS 15 patients serum (HIV-Ig, NIH AIDS Reagent Program) at 4 °C overnight. After 3-time wash with 16 PBS, the bound proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE. The phosphorimages were collected by 17 Typhoon FLA 9000 (GE Healthcare) and quantified by Quantity One software (Bio-Rad).

FIGREF10.text: or intracellular staining by flow cytometry. Cells, permeabilized or without 20 permeabilization, were washed twice with cold PBS plus 2% FBS, detached by PBS containing 5 21 mM EDTA, and incubated with different primary antibodies for 1 h. After three washes with to-cell viral fusion. We combined our cell-to-cell infection assay with a previously 4 described BlaM-Vpr viral fusion method (Cavrois et al., 2002) to measure HIV-1 virion fusion in 5 target cells. Briefly, cell-to-cell infection was performed as described above, except that NL43 6 proviral DNA plus a BlaM-Vpr encoding plasmid (gift of Warner Greene) was cotransfected into 7 293T cells. The transfected 293T cells were cocultured with Jurkat/tdTomato cells for 2 h, and 8 CCF2-AM substrate-containing medium was loaded. Cells were washed, and loaded with 9 developing medium containing 10% FBS, and incubated in dark at room temperature for 16 10 hours before being fixed in 3.7% formaldehyde, and analyzed on an LSR II flow cytometer 11 (Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, NJ).

FIGREF12.text: and selection of HIV-1 escape mutants. SupT1 cells were infected with virus 20 equivalent to 10 ng viral p24, and viral replication was monitored by measuring the levels of 21 viral RT activity in supernatants over time. For select of HIV-1 NL4-3 escape mutants, virus was 22 used to infect SupT1 cells that stably express IFITM1Δ(117-125) or none. When cytopathogenic 23

TABREF0.text: (A) Upper panels indicate immunoprecipitation of cell lysates with anti-FLAG conjugated beads. Lower panels show cell lysates input. Note that IFITMs appear to interact with different forms of gp160 (top panel). (B). Upper panels indicate immunoprecipitation of virions HIV-Ig conjugated beads. Lower panels show concentrated virion inputs.
